awd_titl_txt: Metal Complexes of Donor-Bridge Acceptor Biradical Ligands: Testing Models for Electron Transport
awd_abstract_narration:
In this project funded by the Chemical Structure, Dynamic & Mechanism B Program of the Chemistry Division, Professor David A. Shultz of the Department of Chemistry at North Carolina State University is studying detailed relationships between a molecule's structure and its capacity to transport electrons in molecule-based electronic devices.  The goal of this research is to develop lucid connections between a molecule's shape/structure and its ability to transport electrons in an electrical circuit.  The results could have application in the next generation of molecular electronics and "spintronics" (electron spin-based electronics).  The project requires detailed studies of molecular synthesis, structure determination, spectroscopy, theory, and is well-suited to the education of scientists.  The Shultz group has extensive experience in training scientists (including undergraduates and those from underrepresented groups) who go on to careers in academia, government laboratories, industry, and entrepreneurship.  Outreach activities include hosting and training undergraduate summer researchers from Shaw University, a local Historically Black University.  

Electron donor-acceptor interactions control electron transfer and transport at the molecular level.  They are crucial, foundational elements in biological and artificial electron transfer and photosynthesis, solar energy conversion and molecular electronics/spintronics (electron spin-based electronics).  The research continues the efforts toward an elucidation of electronic coupling in Donor-Bridge-Acceptor systems in which the donor fragment is a metal-semiquinone and the acceptor is a nitronylnitroxide radical, and the magnetic electron spin-spin exchange coupling between the two is directly proportional to the square of the Donor-Acceptor electronic coupling.  The focus is on elucidating factors affecting molecular current rectification, and molecular design elements that might serve as tunnel junctions in molecular current rectifiers (e.g., cross-conjugation and non-alternate hydrocarbons).

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
The NSF-funded project, "Metal Complexes of Donor-Bridge Acceptor Biradical Ligands: Testing Models for Electron Transport" has resulted in building a substantial knowledge base of new molecules and molecular properties related to current flow in molecular electronics. Our findings will be of interest to synthetic chemists, theoreticians, and materials chemists. Our results help create a future workforce equipped with the fundamental knowledge to drive advances in molecule-based materials.

Specifically, we have designed, prepared, and characterized over two dozen new molecules with interesting and unprecedented properties. Characterization includes determining molecular structures using X-ray diffraction and a variety of spectroscopic methods. These new molecules display remarkable changes in spectroscopic and magnetic properties as a function of temperature and metal ion coordination.  Since we prepared and structurally characterized such a large number of molecules, we were able to correlate molecular magnetic properties with bond lengths -- a very fundamental correlation that to our knowledge has not been observed previously. In addition, we have demonstrated -- for the first time -- how a molecules structure changes as a response to metal ion coordination. In our unique case, different metal ions with the same charge, but different magnetic properties result in different bridging molecule bond lengths.  The bond length differences are driven by magnetic properties!

Previous theoretical models for such molecules were either too simple or too complex to allow for straightforward understanding of their properties.  We have developed a simple model base on symmetry that provides a complete picture of the bonding and properties of this class of molecules. Our results help create a future workforce equipped with the fundamental knowledge to drive advances in molecule-based materials.



Last Modified: 08/16/2023
Modified by: David A Shultz

Image
  • The molecule pictured displays unprecedented changes in magnetic properties and color. The spectra shown display the color changes.
    Shultz Group

    Remarkable Temperature Dependent Spectra
